children.subject:
+1

If you're on the fence about taking the internship, considee not if only out of principle to discourage companies asking for free labor (the one exception maybe is if it's purely a learning experience and you know you won't be writing any production code)

You should not take an unpaid internship at all. This really just shows that the startup is run by people who don’t know what they are doing (and want your free labor) or are just jerks. In these cases, you can learn more doing personal projects or contributing to open source (where you will generally learn even more).

if you're considering joining a tech club that does a lot of projects for recruiting benefits, that's basically the same as an unpaid internship. Except on a resume, the unpaid internship would be weighted more heavily than a club and would be more beneficial for recruiting.  If you're taking 70, definitely wait to start until the fall to start (and tbh, keep talking to other companies and see if you can find something that'll compensate you)

I agree with the others who are raising concerns about the unpaid nature of the internship - definitely do some research into the company before accepting, and try to negotiate for at least clear boundaries of how many hours a week you would be expected to work, etc. Get all of it in writing. Try to negotiate for at least minimum wage if you can; the company clearly sees that you have value, and you should value yourself too.

Thank you guys so much for the input! One reason why I was seriously consider doing this internship was because people told me clubs are basically like unpaid internships, but an actual internship are weighed more heavily on resumes to recruiters, who also won’t know if the internship was paid or not  /:

history.content:
Hi! I was recently offered a position as a backend software engineering intern by a small startup (unpaid). I interviewed and was told to think about when I want to start. Here is what I'm thinking.

Starting in the summer: I am taking CS 70 in the summer and I'm LSCS so maybe starting this summer isn't a good idea. However, this would be a good experience to talk about with recruiters during the fall.

My next option would be starting in the fall, but I also want to join a club, and combined with recruiting, I would have little time.

My question is, would it be rude to ask them to start in the spring? Or should I just take the opportunity and do it summer/fall? Thanks in advance for the advice!
history.subject: Unpaid internship vs. club
